ca0.desc: Shows how the finite speed of light and the great distances to most astronomical objects cause us to observe things as they were in the past.
ca0.title: Lookback Time Simulator

ca1.desc: Shows how small angles can be approximated.
ca1.title: Small-Angle Approximation Demonstrator

ca2.desc: Demonstrates how the day of the year when a star is first visible in the morning (the heliacal rising) depends on the observer's latitude and the star's position on the celestial sphere.
ca2.title: Heliacal Rising Simulator

ca3.desc: Shows how stars rotate around the North Star over time (both daily and seasonal motions are shown).
ca3.title: Big Dipper Clock

ca4.desc: Shows the geometry for calculating the meridional altitude of objects.
ca4.title: Meridional Altitude Simulator

ca5.desc: Shows how an observer's latitude determines the circumpolar, rise and set, and never rise regions in the sky.
ca5.title: Declination Ranges Simulator

ca6.desc: Shows how the sun's declination and right ascension change over the course of a year.
ca6.title: Ecliptic Simulator

ca7.desc: Demonstrates the changing declination of the sun with a time-lapse movie, which shows how the shadow of a building changes over the course of a year.
ca7.title: Union Seasons Demonstrator

ca8.desc: Demonstrates the horizon coordinate system, where altitude and azimuth define an object's position in the sky.
ca8.title: Azimuth/Altitude Demonstrator

ca9.desc: Simulation showing daylight and nighttime regions on a flat map of Earth.  Daily and yearly motions of the sunlight pattern can be shown.
ca9.title: Daylight Simulator

ca11.desc: Shows the sun's position in the sky relative to the background stars (the zodiac constellations) over the course of a year.
ca11.title: Ecliptic (Zodiac) Simulator

ca12.desc: Demonstrates latitude and longitude with an interactive globe, providing an analogy to the celestial and horizon coordinate systems.
ca12.title: Longitude/Latitude Demonstrator

ca13.desc: Demonstrates the celestial-equatorial (RA/dec) coordinate system, where declination and right ascension define an object's position on the celestial sphere.
ca13.title: Celestial-Equatorial (RA/Dec) Demonstrator

ca14.desc: Shows how the declination of the sun varies over the course of a year using a horizon diagram.
ca14.title: Paths of the Sun

ca15.desc: Shows the paths of the sun on the celestial sphere.
ca15.title: Sun Motions Overview

ca16.desc: Models the motions of the sun in the sky using a horizon diagram, demonstrating daily and seasonal changes in the sun's position.
ca16.title: Sun Motions Demonstrator

ca17.desc: Shows how the sun's most direct rays hit different parts of the earth as the seasons change.
ca17.title: Sun's Rays Simulator

ca18.desc: Shows how the direction of the sun at sunrise or sunset changes over the course of the year.
ca18.title: Sun's Position on Horizon

ca19.desc: Demonstrates how the stars of the big dipper, which are at various distance from earth, project onto the celestial sphere to give the familiar asterism.
ca19.title: Big Dipper 3D

ca20.desc: Shows the geometry of the earth and sun over the course of a year, demonstrating how seasons occur. This simulator allows both orbital and celestial sphere representations of the seasonal motions.
ca20.title: Seasons Simulator (NAAP)

ca21.desc: Shows how the rotation of the earth leads to the apparent rotation of the sky, and how celestial sphere and horizon diagram representations of the sky are correlated.
ca21.title: Coordinate Systems Comparison

ca22.desc: Shows the hours of daylight received during the year for an observer at a given latitude. This is an important factor contributing to the seasons.
ca22.title: Daylight Hours Explorer

ca23.desc: Demonstrates antipodal points, which are points on opposite sides of the Earth from each other.
ca23.title: Antipodes Explorer

ca24.desc: Shows how sidereal time and the hour angle of a star are related.
ca24.title: Sidereal Time and Hour Angle Demonstrator

ca25.desc: Demonstrates how the celestial sphere and horizon diagram are related.
ca25.title: Celestial and Horizon Systems Comparison

ca26.desc: Helps demonstrate the difference between sidereal and solar time.
ca26.title: Sidereal and Solar Time Simulator

ca27.desc: Shows the appearance of the moon at each of the named moon phases.
ca27.title: Lunar Phase Vocabulary

ca28.desc: Shows an illuminated basketball that can be viewed from multiple directions, providing an analogy to moon phases.
ca28.title: Basketball Phases Simulator

ca29.desc: Shows how the phase of the moon depends on the viewing geometry by allowing the moon to be viewed from the earth, the sun, and an arbitrary point in space.
ca29.title: Three Views Simulator

ca30.desc: Demonstrates the correspondence between the moon's position in its orbit, its phase, and its position in an observer's sky at different times of day.
ca30.title: Lunar Phases Simulator (NAAP)

ca31.desc: Demonstrates how the inclination of the moon's orbit precludes eclipses most of the time, leading to distinct eclipse seasons.
ca31.title: Moon Inclination

ca32.desc: Consists of a table of solar and lunar eclipses, showing the banding that represents the eclipse seasons that occur about twice a year.
ca32.title: Eclipse Table

ca33.desc: Provides draggable earth and moon discs with shadows, which can be used to demonstrate how the umbral (complete) and penumbral (partial) shadows give rise to different types of eclipses.
ca33.title: Eclipse Shadow Simulator

ca34.desc: Shows how the sun, moon, and earth's rotation combine to create tides.
ca34.title: Tidal Bulge Simulation

ca35.desc: Demonstrates how planet and moon phases depend on orbital geometry. Users can drag two bodies around to see how the observed appearances change.
ca35.title: Phase Positions Demonstrator

ca36.desc: Provides a method of learning the correlation between the phase of the moon, the time of day, and the position of the moon in the sky.
ca36.title: Moon Phases and the Horizon Diagram

ca37.desc: Demonstrates the difference between a sidereal and synodic (solar) day, which arises from the earth's revolution around the sun.
ca37.title: Synodic Lag

ca38.desc: Shows the declination range of the full moon over the course of a year, and the corresponding changes in altitude for a northern hemisphere observer.
ca38.title: Full Moon Declination Simulator

ca39.desc: Shows the standard orbital view of the Moon, but with the option to hide the Moon's phase, the Moon's position, or the Sun's direction.
ca39.title: Lunar Phase Quizzer

ca40.desc: Demonstrates a method for determining moon phases using planes that bisect the earth and moon.
ca40.title: Moon Phases With Bisectors

ca41.desc: Shows what Venus looks like through a telescope as the planets go around in their orbits. Compare with the Ptolemaic Phases of Venus simulation.
ca41.title: Phases of Venus

ca42.desc: Shows what Venus would look like through a telescope if Ptolemy's model was correct. Compare with the other Phases of Venus simulation.
ca42.title: Ptolemaic Phases of Venus

ca43.desc: Shows Ptolemy's model for the orbit of Mars.
ca43.title: Ptolemaic Orbit of Mars

ca44.desc: Demonstrates that the heliocentric and geocentric models are equivalent for predictive purposes when limited to circular orbits. One can watch the same system in motion with different bodies held in fixed position.
ca44.title: Epicycles Demo

ca45.desc: Demonstrates the retrograde motion of Mars with an annotated animation.
ca45.title: Retrograde Motion

ca46.desc: Lets one calculate the period of a planet from its semimajor axis, and vice versa.
ca46.title: Kepler's Third Law

ca47.desc: Lets one calculate the sidereal period of the planet (P) from the synodic period (S), and vice versa.
ca47.title: Synodic Period Calculator

ca48.desc: Models the movements of the planets around the sun in a simplified Copernican model of the solar system.
ca48.title: Planetary Configurations Simulator (NAAP)

ca49.desc: Models the motion of a hypothetical planet that orbits the sun according to Kepler's laws of motion. This simulator includes controls for investigating each of Kepler's laws.
ca49.title: Planetary Orbit Simulator (NAAP)

ca50.desc: Demonstrates the parameters that define the eccentricity of an ellipse.
ca50.title: Eccentricity Demonstrator

ca51.desc: Shows the orbital period as a function of orbital distance for satellites of Earth.
ca51.title: Earth Orbit Plot

ca52.desc: Allows one to calculate the force of gravity acting on a variety of masses over a range of distances.
ca52.title: Newton's Law of Gravity Calculator

ca53.desc: Shows how the force of gravity would be different if the values used in Newton's law of universal gravitation formula are changed.
ca53.title: Gravity Algebra

ca54.desc: A movie showing the heating and eventual melting of a nail, and the theoretical blackbody curve produced in the process.
ca54.title: Blackbody Curves of Melting

ca55.desc: Allows one to generate a variety of simulated spectra, depending on factors such as the type of source, luminosity class, spectral type, and individually selected elements.
ca55.title: Spectrum Explorer

ca56.desc: Surveys the electromagnetic spectrum, showing a typical astronomical image for different wavelengths of light and the kind of instrument that would take such an image.
ca56.title: EM Spectrum Module

ca57.desc: Demonstrates how the blackbody spectrum varies with temperature. This explorer also shows how the relative intensities observed through different filters (a 'color index') can give an estimate of temperature.
ca57.title: Blackbody Curves (NAAP)

ca58.desc: Demonstrates how different light sources and filters combine to determine an observed spectrum. This simulator also shows the perceived colors associated with the spectra shown.
ca58.title: Filters Simulator (NAAP)

ca59.desc: Models a hydrogen atom and its interactions with light, demonstrating the quantum nature of absorption and emission.
ca59.title: Hydrogen Atom Simulator (NAAP)

ca60.desc: Demonstrates how different spectra can arise from a light bulb (a thermal source) and a cold, thin gas cloud. The spectrometer shows emission, absorption, or continuous spectra based on where the draggable telescope is pointed.
ca60.title: Three Views Spectrum Demonstrator

ca61.desc: Demonstrates how the spectrum of a star is shifted as it and its planet orbit their common center of mass.
ca61.title: Extrasolar Planet Radial Velocity Demonstrator

ca62.desc: Shows circular waves expanding from a source. Movement of the source or observer affects the frequency of the waves seen by the observer, demonstrating doppler shift.
ca62.title: Doppler Shift Demonstrator

ca63.desc: Demonstrates the properties of a telescope, and how these vary with aperture and eyepiece selection.
ca63.title: Telescope Simulator

ca64.desc: Shows a rainfall and bucket analogy to CCD imaging.
ca64.title: CCD Simulator

ca65.desc: Demonstrates Snell's Law, a formula that describes how light is refracted when it moves between different media.
ca65.title: Snell's Law Demonstrator

ca66.desc: Shows an animated diagram of the proton-proton chain reaction, which is the dominant fusion reaction in the sun's core.
ca66.title: Proton-Proton Animation

ca67.desc: Shows an animated diagram of the CNO cycle, which dominates in stars larger than the sun.
ca67.title: CNO Cycle Animation

ca68.desc: Shows how the distance modulus formula combines apparent and absolute magnitudes to give the distance to a star.
ca68.title: Distance Modulus Explorer

ca69.desc: Shows how the distance to a star, its doppler shift, and its proper motion allow one to calculate the star's true space velocity.
ca69.title: Stellar Velocity Calculator

ca70.desc: Diagrams the geometry and shows the math involved in determining a star's distance via parallax.
ca70.title: Parallax Calculator

ca71.desc: Demonstrates how the technique of spectroscopic parallax works. Spectral type and luminosity class determine the observed spectrum of a star, from which the star's luminosity can be estimated.
ca71.title: Spectroscopic Parallax Simulator

ca72.desc: Demonstrates how a star's luminosity depends on its temperature and radius.
ca72.title: Stellar Luminosity Calculator

ca73.desc: Demonstrates the inverse square law of light with a lightbulb and detector. The lightbulb's intensity and the detector's distance can be adjusted to see how they affect the reading. There are two bulbs and detectors to allow side-by-side comparisons.
ca73.title: Flux Simulator

ca74.desc: Introduces the Hertzsprung-Russell Diagram, a plot showing the relationship between luminosity and temperature for stars.
ca74.title: HR Explorer (NAAP)

ca75.desc: Models the motions of two stars in orbit around each other, and the combined lightcurve they produce. This simulator allows the user to control multiple parameters to see how they effect the lightcurve. Includes several real datasets.
ca75.title: Eclipsing Binary Simulator

ca76.desc: Demonstrates aliasing through the analogy of a wagon wheel being filmed. For some combinations of frame rates and true rotation speeds the wheel can appear to rotate backwards.
ca76.title: Aliasing in Wagon Wheels

ca77.desc: Shows how the center of mass of two objects changes as their masses change.
ca77.title: Center of Mass Simulator

ca78.desc: Shows how a lightcurve is constructed from observations of an eclipsing binary system.
ca78.title: Lightcurve Simulator

ca79.desc: A plot of the rotational velocity of stars at varying distances from the center of the milky way. A draggable cursor allows determining the contained mass implied by the curve.
ca79.title: Milky Way Rotational Velocity

ca80.desc: The build-up of traffic behind a slow moving tractor provides an analogy to the density wave formation of spiral arms.
ca80.title: Traffic Density Analogy

ca81.desc: An animation of coins attached to a balloon, providing an analogy to the expansion of the universe. The coins represent galaxies, which maintain their scale while the space between them grows.
ca81.title: Balloon Universe

ca82.desc: Demonstrates the redshift of a galaxy due to the expansion of the universe, and the effect this shift has on the galaxy's brightness as observed through various filters.
ca82.title: Galactic Redshift Simulator

ca83.desc: Shows planet formation temperature as a function of distance from the Sun. Also indicates the state (gas or solid) of several substances at the given distance and temperature.
ca83.title: Planet Formation Temperatures Plot

ca84.desc: Allows one to explore a set of histograms for characteristics like number of satellites, mass, orbital period, etc. for the terrestial and jovian planets, plus Pluto.
ca84.title: Solar System Properties Explorer

ca85.desc: Shows the movement of the sun due to the gravitational pull of the planets. The contribution from each planet can be isolated by toggling checkboxes.
ca85.title: Influence of Planets on the Sun

ca86.desc: Shows a star and planet in orbit around each other while tracing out the star's radial velocity curve.
ca86.title: Radial Velocity Graph

ca87.desc: Demonstrates how a planet passing in front of its parent star can cause dips in the star's lightcurve, potentially leading to the planet's detection.
ca87.title: Transit Simulator (NAAP)

ca88.desc: Demonstrates how the spectrum of a star is shifted as it and its planet orbit their common center of mass.
ca88.title: Extrasolar Planet Radial Velocity Demonstrator

ca89.desc: Models the motion of an extrasolar planet and its star around their common center of mass, and the effect this motion has on the star's observed radial velocity.
ca89.title: Radial Velocity Simulator (NAAP)

ca90.desc: Shows circular waves expanding from a source. Movement of the source or observer affects the frequency of the waves seen by the observer, demonstrating doppler shift.
ca90.title: Doppler Shift Demonstrator

ca91.desc: Demonstrates how the movement of a pulsar and planet around their common center of mass affects the timing of pulse arrivals.
ca91.title: Pulsar Period Simulator

ca92.desc: Illustrates how the movement of a star and its planet about their center of mass compares to a hammer thrower swinging a heavy metal ball.
ca92.title: Hammer Thrower Comparison

ca93.desc: Shows a snow shower from the perspective of a car driving through it, demonstrating how the snow seems to diverge from some central point (the radiant). Provides an analogy to a meteor shower.
ca93.title: Driving Through Snow

ca94.desc: Models the movements of the planets around the sun in a simplified Copernican model of the solar system.
ca94.title: Planetary Configurations Simulator (NAAP)

ca95.desc: Models the motion of a hypothetical planet that orbits the sun according to Kepler's laws of motion. This simulator includes controls for investigating each of Kepler's laws.
ca95.title: Planetary Orbit Simulator (NAAP)

ca96.desc: Shows how sidereal time and the hour angle of a star are related.
ca96.title: Sidereal Time and Hour Angle Demonstrator

naap0.desc: Models the movements of the planets around the sun in a simplified Copernican model of the solar system.
naap0.title: Planetary Configurations Simulator

naap1.desc: Demonstrates how Ptolemy's geocentric model accounts for the movements of the planets.
naap1.title: Ptolemaic System Simulator

naap2.desc: Shows the geometry of the earth and sun over the course of a year, demonstrating how seasons occur. This simulator allows both orbital and celestial sphere representations of the seasonal motions.
naap2.title: Seasons and Ecliptic Simulator

naap3.desc: Shows how the rotation of the earth leads to the apparent rotation of the sky, and how celestial sphere and horizon diagram representations of the sky are correlated.
naap3.title: Rotating Sky Explorer

naap4.desc: Models the motions of the sun in the sky using a horizon diagram, demonstrating daily and seasonal changes in the sun's position.
naap4.title: Motions of the Sun Simulator

naap5.desc: Helps demonstrate the difference between sidereal and solar time.
naap5.title: Sidereal and Solar Time Simulator

naap6.desc: Models the motion of a hypothetical planet that orbits the sun according to Kepler's laws of motion. This simulator includes controls for investigating each of Kepler's laws.
naap6.title: Planetary Orbit Simulator

naap7.desc: Outlines a proceedure for determining moon phases by using bisectors (planes that divide the moon in two halves).
naap7.title: Moon Bisector Demo

naap8.desc: Demonstrates the correspondence between the moon's position in its orbit, its phase, and its position in an observer's sky at different times of day.
naap8.title: Lunar Phase Simulator

naap9.desc: Provides a method of learning the correlation between the phase of the moon, the time of day, and the position of the moon in the sky.
naap9.title: Moon Phases and the Horizon Diagram

naap10.desc: Demonstrates how the blackbody spectrum varies with temperature. This explorer also shows how the relative intensities observed through different filters (a 'color index') can give an estimate of temperature.
naap10.title: Blackbody Curves and Filters Explorer

naap11.desc: Demonstrates how different light sources and filters combine to determine an observed spectrum. This simulator also shows the perceived colors associated with the spectra shown.
naap11.title: Light and Filters Simulator

naap12.desc: Models a hydrogen atom and its interactions with light, demonstrating the quantum nature of absorption and emission.
naap12.title: Hydrogen Atom Simulator

naap13.desc: Introduces the Hertzsprung-Russell Diagram, a plot showing the relationship between luminosity and temperature for stars.
naap13.title: Hertzsprung-Russell Diagram Explorer

naap14.desc: Models the motions of two stars in orbit around each other, and the combined lightcurve they produce. This simulator allows the user to control multiple parameters to see how they effect the lightcurve. Includes several real datasets.
naap14.title: Eclipsing Binary Simulator

naap15.desc: Shows how the molecular mass, temperature, and escape speed determine whether a gas will remain gravitationally bound to a planet.
naap15.title: Gas Retention Plot

naap16.desc: Demonstrates how gases of different molecular masses behave when maintained at thermodynamic equilibrium in a chamber. The chamber can be set to allow particles that exceed a certain speed to escape, providing an analogy for the bleeding of a planet's atmosphere into space.
naap16.title: Gas Retention Simulator

naap17.desc: Models the motion of an extrasolar planet and its star around their common center of mass, and the effect this motion has on the star's observed radial velocity.
naap17.title: Exoplanet Radial Velocity Simulator

naap18.desc: Demonstrates how a planet passing in front of its parent star can cause dips in the star's lightcurve, potentially leading to the planet's detection.
naap18.title: Exoplanet Transit Simulator

naap19.desc: Allows one to adjust the relative positions of three images so that their contents are alligned.
naap19.title: Registration Simulator

naap20.desc: Cycles through multiple images of the same field, revealing variable stars. The variable stars identified in this simulator can then be analyzed with the Variable Star Photometry Analyzer.
naap20.title: Blink Comparator Simulator

naap21.desc: Demonstrates aperture photometry by allowing one to drag aperture discs over a star field.
naap21.title: Photometry Simulator

naap22.desc: Demonstrates variable star analysis through period determination and lightcurve folding.
naap22.title: Variable Star Photometry Analyzer

naap23.desc: Demonstrates the concept of parallax and how it can be used to determine distance using an analogy of a boat on a lake.
naap23.title: Parallax Explorer

naap24.desc: Demonstrates how the technique of spectroscopic parallax works. Spectral type and luminosity class determine the observed spectrum of a star, from which the star's luminosity can be estimated.
naap24.title: Spectroscopic Parallax Simulator

naap25.desc: Allows determining the distance to a cluster by fitting the cluster's stars to the main sequence in an HR diagram.
naap25.title: HR Diagram Star Cluster Fitting Explorer

naap26.desc: Allows determining the distance to a supernova by fitting observations to a theoretical Type Ia curve.
naap26.title: Supernova Light Curve Fitting Explorer

naap27.desc: Demonstrates location and evolution of the stellar habitable zone, which is the region around a star where surface water may exist on a earth like planet.
naap27.title: Circumstellar Habitable Zone Simulator

naap28.desc: Shows how two factors important to life – metallicity and extinction risk – vary throughout the Milky Way Galaxy.
naap28.title: Milky Way Habitability Explorer

titles.name: Demonstrador de aproximação de pequeno ângulo
Visão geral dos movimentos do sol
Explorador de horas de luz do dia
Demonstrador de tempo sideral e ângulo horário
Comparação de sistemas celestes e horizontais
Simulador de Tempo Sideral e Solar
Fases da Lua e o Diagrama do Horizonte
Simulador de Declinação da Lua Cheia
Calculadora da Lei da Gravidade de Newton
Curvas de fusão do corpo negro
Demonstrador de espectro de três visualizações
Demonstrador de velocidade radial de planeta extrasolar
Velocidade de rotação da Via Láctea
Gráfico de temperaturas de formação de planetas
Explorador de Propriedades do Sistema Solar
Demonstrador de velocidade radial de planeta extrasolar
Demonstrador de tempo sideral e ângulo horário
Simulador de Tempo Sideral e Solar
Fases da Lua e o Diagrama do Horizonte
Explorador de Curvas e Filtros de Corpo Negro
Simulador de velocidade radial de exoplanetas
Analisador de fotometria de estrelas variáveis
Diagrama HR Explorador de ajuste de aglomerados estelares
Explorador de ajuste de curva de luz Supernova
Explorador de Habitabilidade da Via Láctea
